sci:arg.name: Text
sci:arg.sci:help: The text to be displayed on the label. HTML is allowed (e.g. an icon alongside text).

sci:arg.name: Left Icon
sci:arg.sci:help:
An optional icon can be displayed on the left side of the button.

Type in an icon name, e.g. Alarm or alarm or Phone Square or phone square. A complete list is available here: http://semantic-ui.com/elements/icon.html

sci:arg.name: Right Icon
sci:arg.sci:help:
An optional icon can be displayed on the right side of the button.

Type in an icon name, e.g. Alarm or alarm or Phone Square or phone square. A complete list is available here: http://semantic-ui.com/elements/icon.html

sci:arg.name: Detail
sci:arg.sci:help: A label can contain a detail.

sci:arg.name: Type
sci:arg.sci:help: Type

sci:arg.name: Corner
sci:arg.sci:help: A label can position itself in the corner of a parent element.

sci:arg.name: Tag
sci:arg.sci:help: A label can appear as a tag.

sci:arg.name: Ribbon
sci:arg.sci:help: A label can appear as a ribbon attaching itself to an element.

sci:arg.name: Attached
sci:arg.sci:help: A label can attach to a content segment.

sci:arg.name: Horizontal
sci:arg.sci:help: A horizontal label is formatted to label content along-side it horizontally. (The content that follows the label.)

sci:arg.name: Floating
sci:arg.sci:help: A label can float above the containing element in its top right corner.

sci:arg.name: Variation
sci:arg.sci:help: Variation

sci:arg.name: Basic
sci:arg.sci:help: A basic label is less pronounced. Just an outline and text inside it are visible.

sci:arg.name: Size
sci:arg.sci:help: A label can be displayed in a variety of sizes.

sci:arg.name: Color
sci:arg.sci:help: Default color is gray.

sci:arg.name: Circular
sci:arg.sci:help: A button can be circular.

sci:arg.name: On Click
sci:arg.sci:help:
JavaScript code to be executed on label click.

To use this label as a link, type window.location.href = "http://mywebsite.com";

To use this label as a protocol link, type window.location.href = "/auth/launchjob?_compat=1&_protocol=myprotocolguid";
where myprotocolguid is your protocol's GUID.

Note: to open the link url in a new window, use window.open instead of window.location.href

sci:arg.name: Constant GUID
sci:arg.sci:help: If set, this will be the ID of the HTML element. If left blank, an ID will be assigned automatically. Only alphanumeric characters are allowed, no spaces or special characters.
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails(ParameterName() . ' must be alphanumeric. Spaces or special characters are not allowed.'); numValues(rMatch(Parameter(), '[^a-zA-Z0-9]+', 'ig')) == 0;

sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma delimited list of global properties, each of which will automatically hold the name of a file in the job's temporary folder, whose name is guaranteed to be unique.

For each global name, an additional global is created (with the suffix _Filename) that hold just the leaf file name of the temporary file.

sci:arg.name: DeclareLocal
sci:arg.sci:help:
Lists a set of properties (without the @) to create on the global property list for this subprotocol. Such properties can only be accessed within the scope of this subprotocol and its descendent subprotocols.

Any global property not declared in this way is created on the top level global property list and is accessible from all protocols, but may collide with another property of the same name.

Scoping global properties to the subprotocol where they are used is highly recommended.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion
sci:arg.sci:help:
When RunToCompletion is set to "True - For Each Data Record", the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each individual data record it processes.

When set to "True - For Each Category", the data records are divided into categories based on the value of the Categorize Using parameter and then the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each category of data records. When used in conjunction with Parallel Processing Options, each category of data records will be sent to the remote server as part of one single batch.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion Categorize Using
sci:arg.sci:help: Required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category, this parameter specifies the property or properties used to define the categories.
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category'); Parameter() ne '';
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To Enable, Set RunToCompletion to True - For Each Category'); Parameter('RunToCompletion') eq 'True - For Each Category';

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
When set to True, this set of options allow the subprotocol to execute in parallel on one or more independent Pipeline Pilot servers, running local or remote. Additional parameters control the number of data records to send in each process batch, the list of Pipeline Pilot servers to use, the number of protocol processes that can be executed on each server, and whether to preserve the order of the processed data records.

Use this option judiciously, since it will not increase throughput in all circumstances. In general, it will yield improved performance when the parallelization benefits outweigh the data transfer overhead for the specified batch size. As a rough guide, performance can be improved when each individual batch requires at least 10 seconds to execute, although this can be affected by the size of each data record.

When running the protocol with debugging, the subprotocol will provide debugging messages to detail each of the various steps of execution. Also, components located within the parallel subprotocol will display their debugging messages as well.

For more information on the parallel subprotocol options, see Parallel Processing Subprotocols.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Batch Size
sci:arg.sci:help:
The number of records to send to the remote server(s) for each subprotocol execution. In general, performance is optimized when the amount of time required to process each batch is at least 10 seconds (note that this can vary depending on the characteristics of the remote server's hardware). Use a batch size of -1 to pass all data in a single batch.

When RunToCompletion is set to "True - for each category", the batch sizes will be determined by the number of records in each individual category. Therefore, the Batch Size parameter is not applicable.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server
sci:arg.sci:help:
Comma separated list of Pipeline Pilot servers on which to execute the parallel subprotocol. The server names should be in the same format as the Pipeline Pilot Client's change server dialog (server-name:port-number).

Specifying localhost as a server will cause the subprotocol to use its own Pipeline Pilot server. This can be helpful on multi-CPU/multi-core systems (where the subprotocol jobs are spawned on the same machine) and Pipeline Pilot Linux clusters (where 'localhost' requests spawning the subprotocol jobs on the same cluster).
sci:arg.sci:member: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required.'); Parameter() ne '';
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Processes
sci:arg.sci:help: Comma separated list of maximum number of batches that can be simultaneously executed on each remote server. The number of entries in this parameter must equal the number of servers. If '*' is specified as the number of processes, then that server will only launch as many batches as the administrator of the remote server has permitted.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid
sci:arg.sci:help: Run subprotocol on grid engine if available.
sci:arg.sci:member: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Queue Name
Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Grid Options
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Queue Name
sci:arg.sci:help: Select the queue name on the grid to submit jobs to. Leave blank to use default queue name.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Grid Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Use this to specify grid engine specific command line parameters to the job submission command. Leave blank to use defaults.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Preserve Order
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether to preserve the order of the data as it enters and leaves the remote subprotocol.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: Popup
sci:arg.sci:help: A popup displays additional information in a temporary message.

sci:arg.name: Popup Content
sci:arg.sci:help: Popup content. (HTML is allowed).

sci:arg.name: Basic Popup
sci:arg.sci:help: A popup can provide basic or extended formatting.

sci:arg.name: Popup Appearance
sci:arg.sci:help: Appearance
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To enable '.ParameterName().', set Basic Popup to False'); not Parameter('Basic Popup');

sci:arg.name: Popup Width
sci:arg.sci:help: A popup can be wide or very wide to allow for longer content.

sci:arg.name: Fluid Popup
sci:arg.sci:help: A fluid popup will take up the entire width of its container.

sci:arg.name: Popup Size
sci:arg.sci:help: A popup can vary in font size.

sci:arg.name: Flowing Popup
sci:arg.sci:help: A popup can have no maximum width and continue to flow to fit its content.

sci:arg.name: Inverted Popup
sci:arg.sci:help: A popup can have its colors inverted.

sci:arg.name: Behavior
sci:arg.sci:help: Behavior

sci:arg.name: Show On
sci:arg.sci:help: When to show the popup. Hover (mouseover), click, focus (when a form element such as a text box is in focus).

sci:arg.name: ProtocolAutoLayout
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol AutoLayout

sci:arg.name: ComponentRevision
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Revision

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Records passing out of any unconnected pass ports of components inside the subprotocol
Records passing out of any unconnected fail ports of components inside the subprotocol

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: Protocol Sticky Notes
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Sticky Notes

sci:arg.name: ProtocolScale2
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Scale

sci:arg.name: Protocol Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Options

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: ProcessingOrder
sci:arg.sci:help: Processing Order

sci:arg.name: OriginalPackage
sci:arg.sci:help: OriginalPackage

sci:arg.name: OriginalComponentGUID
sci:arg.sci:help: OriginalComponentGUID

sci:arg.name: ByReference
sci:arg.sci:help: By Ref

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma delimited list of global properties, each of which will automatically hold the name of a file in the job's temporary folder, whose name is guaranteed to be unique.

For each global name, an additional global is created (with the suffix _Filename) that hold just the leaf file name of the temporary file.

Lists a set of properties (without the @) to create on the global property list for this subprotocol. Such properties can only be accessed within the scope of this subprotocol and its descendent subprotocols.

Any global property not declared in this way is created on the top level global property list and is accessible from all protocols, but may collide with another property of the same name.

Scoping global properties to the subprotocol where they are used is highly recommended.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion
sci:arg.sci:help:
When RunToCompletion is set to "True - For Each Data Record", the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each individual data record it processes.

When set to "True - For Each Category", the data records are divided into categories based on the value of the Categorize Using parameter and then the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each category of data records. When used in conjunction with Parallel Processing Options, each category of data records will be sent to the remote server as part of one single batch.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion Categorize Using
sci:arg.sci:help: Required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category, this parameter specifies the property or properties used to define the categories.
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category'); Parameter() ne '';
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To Enable, Set RunToCompletion to True - For Each Category'); Parameter('RunToCompletion') eq 'True - For Each Category';

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
When set to True, this set of options allow the subprotocol to execute in parallel on one or more independent Pipeline Pilot servers, running local or remote. Additional parameters control the number of data records to send in each process batch, the list of Pipeline Pilot servers to use, the number of protocol processes that can be executed on each server, and whether to preserve the order of the processed data records.

Use this option judiciously, since it will not increase throughput in all circumstances. In general, it will yield improved performance when the parallelization benefits outweigh the data transfer overhead for the specified batch size. As a rough guide, performance can be improved when each individual batch requires at least 10 seconds to execute, although this can be affected by the size of each data record.

When running the protocol with debugging, the subprotocol will provide debugging messages to detail each of the various steps of execution. Also, components located within the parallel subprotocol will display their debugging messages as well.

For more information on the parallel subprotocol options, see Parallel Processing Subprotocols.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Batch Size

The number of records to send to the remote server(s) for each subprotocol execution. In general, performance is optimized when the amount of time required to process each batch is at least 10 seconds (note that this can vary depending on the characteristics of the remote server's hardware). Use a batch size of -1 to pass all data in a single batch.

When RunToCompletion is set to "True - for each category", the batch sizes will be determined by the number of records in each individual category. Therefore, the Batch Size parameter is not applicable.

Specifying localhost as a server will cause the subprotocol to use its own Pipeline Pilot server. This can be helpful on multi-CPU/multi-core systems (where the subprotocol jobs are spawned on the same machine) and Pipeline Pilot Linux clusters (where 'localhost' requests spawning the subprotocol jobs on the same cluster).

sci:arg.name: Protocol Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Options

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: OriginalPackage
sci:arg.sci:help: OriginalPackage

sci:arg.name: SubProtocolMadeLinkIntoCopy
sci:arg.sci:help: Subprotocol Made Link Into Copy

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.name: Expression
sci:arg.sci:help: Expression (or list of expressions separated by semi-colons) to evaluate.

sci:arg.name: Initial Expression
sci:arg.sci:help:
This expression is executed only the first time data passes into the component.

Since there is no data available at initialization time, only expressions referencing local or global properties are allowed.

sci:arg.name: Final Expression
sci:arg.sci:help:
This expression is executed only at finalization (after the last data passes out of the component).

Since there is no data available at finalization time, only expressions referencing local or global properties are allowed.

sci:arg.name: Keep Calculated Properties
sci:arg.sci:help: Adds any properties calculated in this component to a data record's property list.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: Do Screen
sci:arg.sci:help: When TRUE, controls which exit port is used for each data record by evaluating the final expression (or only one) listed in the "Expression" parameter. -Pass (green) port when expression true -Fail (red) port when expression false

sci:arg.name: ExpressionVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: Version of expression parser to use.

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: ComponentAutoDisplayName
sci:arg.sci:help: Automatically update the component display name when the "Expression" property is changed. This feature is turned off after the user manually changes the display name of the component in Protocol workspace.

sci:arg.name: DerivedFrom
sci:arg.sci:help: The component this component is based upon.

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value: Applies a PilotScript expression to each data record

PilotScript is the native scripting language in Pipeline Pilot. It is based on PL/SQL and allows you to query or alter the properties on data records. For example, the expression:

A := 10;
creates a property named "A" and sets the value to "10".

For each incoming data record the PilotScript statements in Expression are evaluated.

Notes:

  • To initialize global variables such as counters, use Initial Expression.
  • To clean up global variables or calculate final results use Final Expression.
  • Parameters on Custom Manipulators do not become global variables that can be accessed via @ParameterName syntax. They must be accessed by using the Parameter('ParameterName') function or by using token substitution via $(ParameterName) syntax.

See Also:

  • For more information on PilotScript, see PilotScript Overview.
  • To use PilotScript to filter data records use Custom Filter (PilotScript).

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma delimited list of global properties, each of which will automatically hold the name of a file in the job's temporary folder, whose name is guaranteed to be unique.

For each global name, an additional global is created (with the suffix _Filename) that hold just the leaf file name of the temporary file.

sci:arg.name: DeclareLocal
sci:arg.sci:help:
Lists a set of properties (without the @) to create on the global property list for this subprotocol. Such properties can only be accessed within the scope of this subprotocol and its descendent subprotocols.

Any global property not declared in this way is created on the top level global property list and is accessible from all protocols, but may collide with another property of the same name.

Scoping global properties to the subprotocol where they are used is highly recommended.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion
sci:arg.sci:help:
When RunToCompletion is set to "True - For Each Data Record", the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each individual data record it processes.

When set to "True - For Each Category", the data records are divided into categories based on the value of the Categorize Using parameter and then the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each category of data records. When used in conjunction with Parallel Processing Options, each category of data records will be sent to the remote server as part of one single batch.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion Categorize Using
sci:arg.sci:help: Required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category, this parameter specifies the property or properties used to define the categories.
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category'); Parameter() ne '';
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To Enable, Set RunToCompletion to True - For Each Category'); Parameter('RunToCompletion') eq 'True - For Each Category';

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
When set to True, this set of options allow the subprotocol to execute in parallel on one or more independent Pipeline Pilot servers, running local or remote. Additional parameters control the number of data records to send in each process batch, the list of Pipeline Pilot servers to use, the number of protocol processes that can be executed on each server, and whether to preserve the order of the processed data records.

Use this option judiciously, since it will not increase throughput in all circumstances. In general, it will yield improved performance when the parallelization benefits outweigh the data transfer overhead for the specified batch size. As a rough guide, performance can be improved when each individual batch requires at least 10 seconds to execute, although this can be affected by the size of each data record.

When running the protocol with debugging, the subprotocol will provide debugging messages to detail each of the various steps of execution. Also, components located within the parallel subprotocol will display their debugging messages as well.

For more information on the parallel subprotocol options, see Parallel Processing Subprotocols.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Batch Size
sci:arg.sci:help:
The number of records to send to the remote server(s) for each subprotocol execution. In general, performance is optimized when the amount of time required to process each batch is at least 10 seconds (note that this can vary depending on the characteristics of the remote server's hardware). Use a batch size of -1 to pass all data in a single batch.

When RunToCompletion is set to "True - for each category", the batch sizes will be determined by the number of records in each individual category. Therefore, the Batch Size parameter is not applicable.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server
sci:arg.sci:help:
Comma separated list of Pipeline Pilot servers on which to execute the parallel subprotocol. The server names should be in the same format as the Pipeline Pilot Client's change server dialog (server-name:port-number).

Specifying localhost as a server will cause the subprotocol to use its own Pipeline Pilot server. This can be helpful on multi-CPU/multi-core systems (where the subprotocol jobs are spawned on the same machine) and Pipeline Pilot Linux clusters (where 'localhost' requests spawning the subprotocol jobs on the same cluster).
sci:arg.sci:member: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required.'); Parameter() ne '';
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

The number of entries in this parameter must equal the number of servers. If '*' is specified as the number of processes, then that server will only launch as many batches as the administrator of the remote server has permitted.

When RunToCompletion is set to "True - For Each Data Record", the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each individual data record it processes.

When set to "True - For Each Category", the data records are divided into categories based on the value of the Categorize Using parameter and then the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each category of data records. sci:arg.sci:help: Required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category, this parameter specifies the property or properties used to define the categories.
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category'); Parameter() ne '';
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To Enable, Set RunToCompletion to True - For Each Category'); Parameter('RunToCompletion') eq 'True - For Each Category';

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
When set to True, this set of options allows the subprotocol to execute in parallel on one or more independent Pipeline Pilot servers, running locally or remotely. Additional parameters control the number of data records to send in each process batch, the list of Pipeline Pilot servers to use, the number of protocol processes that can be executed on each server, and whether to preserve the order of the processed data records.

Use this option with care, since it will not increase throughput in all circumstances. Generally speaking, it yields improved performance when the parallelization benefits outweigh the data transfer overhead for the specified batch size. As a rough guide, performance can be improved when each individual batch requires at least 10 seconds to execute, although this can be affected by the size of each data record.

When running the protocol with debugging, the subprotocol will provide debugging messages to detail each of the various steps of execution. Also, components located within the parallel subprotocol will display their debugging messages as well.

For more information on the parallel subprotocol options, see Parallel Processing Subprotocols.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Batch Size
sci:arg.sci:help:
The number of records to send to the remote server(s) for each subprotocol execution. In general, performance is optimized when the amount of time required to process each batch is at least 10 seconds (note that this can vary depending on the characteristics of the remote server's hardware). Use a batch size of -1 to pass all data in a single batch.

When RunToCompletion is set to "True - for each category", the batch sizes will be determined by the number of records in each individual category. Therefore, the Batch Size parameter is not applicable.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma-separated list of Pipeline Pilot servers on which to execute the parallel subprotocol. The server names should be in the same format as the Pipeline Pilot Client's change server dialog (that is, server-name:port-number).

Specifying localhost as a server will cause the subprotocol to use its own Pipeline Pilot server. This can be useful on multi-CPU/multi-core systems (where the subprotocol jobs are spawned on the same machine) and Pipeline Pilot Linux clusters (where 'localhost' requests spawning the subprotocol jobs on the same cluster).
sci:arg.sci:member: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required.'); Parameter() ne '';
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Processes
sci:arg.sci:help: A comma-separated list of the maximum number of batches that can be simultaneously executed on each remote server. The number of entries in this parameter must equal the number of servers. If '*' is specified as the number of processes, then that server will only launch as many batches as the administrator of the remote server has permitted.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid
sci:arg.sci:help: Run subprotocol on grid engine if available.
sci:arg.sci:member: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Queue Name
Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Grid Options
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Queue Name
sci:arg.sci:help: Select the queue name on the grid to submit jobs to. Leave blank to use default queue name.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid Grid Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Use this to specify grid engine specific command line parameters to the job submission command. Leave blank to use defaults.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: parameter('Parallel Processing Options Server Run On Grid');

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Preserve Order
sci:arg.sci:help: Whether to preserve the order of the data as it enters and leaves the remote subprotocol.
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails("This parameter is only applicable if 'Parallel Processing Options' is 'True'"); Parameter('Parallel Processing Options');

sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma-delimited list of global properties, each of which is automatically populated with the name of a file in the job's temporary folder, which always has a unique name.

For each global name, an additional global is created (with the suffix _Filename) that hold only the leaf file name of the temporary file.

sci:arg.name: DeclareLocal
sci:arg.sci:help:
Lists a set of properties (without the @) to create on the global property list for this subprotocol. Such properties can only be accessed within the scope of this subprotocol and its descendent subprotocols.

Any global property not declared in this way is created on the top-level global property list and is accessible from all subprotocols, but breaks the encapsulation of the subprotocol and may collide with another property of the same name.

Therefore, you should always declare a new global property in the DeclareLocal parameter, to scope the global property to the subprotocol where it is used.
sci:arg.sci:value: Constant GUID, guid, title_, fluid_, inverted_, flowing_

sci:arg.name: ComponentAttributes
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Attributes

sci:arg.name: Popup Content
sci:arg.sci:help: Popup content. (HTML is allowed).

sci:arg.name: Basic Popup
sci:arg.sci:help: A popup can provide basic or extended formatting.

sci:arg.name: Popup Width
sci:arg.sci:help: A popup can be wide or very wide to allow for longer content.

sci:arg.name: Fluid Popup
sci:arg.sci:help: A fluid popup will take up the entire width of its container.

sci:arg.name: Popup Size
sci:arg.sci:help: A popup can vary in font size.

sci:arg.name: Flowing Popup
sci:arg.sci:help: A popup can have no maximum width and continue to flow to fit its content.

sci:arg.name: Inverted Popup
sci:arg.sci:help: A popup can have its colors inverted.

sci:arg.name: Show On
sci:arg.sci:help: When to show the popup. Hover (mouseover), click, focus (when a form element such as a text box is in focus).

sci:arg.name: ProtocolAutoLayout
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol AutoLayout

sci:arg.name: ComponentRevision
sci:arg.sci:help: Component Revision

sci:arg.name: ByReference
sci:arg.sci:help: By Ref

sci:arg.name: ComponentHelp
sci:arg.sci:value:
A popup displays additional information on top of a page element.

This component will attach a pop-up to the page element that appears immediately before it in final page HTML. For example, a button or a label or a text box.

This component will not interfere with page layout because it is contained inside a <script> HTML tag.
Records passing out of any unconnected pass ports of components inside the subprotocol
Records passing out of any unconnected fail ports of components inside the subprotocol

sci:arg.name: RegistrationVersion
sci:arg.sci:help: The server version when this component was registered

sci:arg.name: Protocol Sticky Notes
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Sticky Notes

sci:arg.name: ProtocolScale2
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Scale

sci:arg.name: Protocol Options
sci:arg.sci:help: Protocol Options

sci:arg.name: Registrant
sci:arg.sci:help: The user who registered this component.

sci:arg.name: RegistrationDate
sci:arg.sci:help: The date this component was registered.

sci:arg.name: ComponentLocalID
sci:arg.sci:help: Local Component Identifier

sci:arg.name: ProcessingOrder
sci:arg.sci:help: Processing Order

sci:arg.name: OriginalPackage
sci:arg.sci:help: OriginalPackage

sci:arg.name: Component Path
sci:arg.sci:help: The original path within the database of this component.

sci:arg.name: SubProtocolMadeLinkIntoCopy
sci:arg.sci:help: Subprotocol Made Link Into Copy

sci:arg.name: Tempfiles
sci:arg.sci:help:
A comma delimited list of global properties, each of which will automatically hold the name of a file in the job's temporary folder, whose name is guaranteed to be unique.

For each global name, an additional global is created (with the suffix _Filename) that hold just the leaf file name of the temporary file.

sci:arg.name: DeclareLocal
sci:arg.sci:help:
Lists a set of properties (without the @) to create on the global property list for this subprotocol. Such properties can only be accessed within the scope of this subprotocol and its descendent subprotocols.

Any global property not declared in this way is created on the top level global property list and is accessible from all protocols, but may collide with another property of the same name.

Scoping global properties to the subprotocol where they are used is highly recommended.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion
sci:arg.sci:help:
When RunToCompletion is set to "True - For Each Data Record", the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each individual data record it processes.

When set to "True - For Each Category", the data records are divided into categories based on the value of the Categorize Using parameter and then the subprotocol is re-initialized and executed in its entirety for each category of data records. When used in conjunction with Parallel Processing Options, each category of data records will be sent to the remote server as part of one single batch.

sci:arg.name: RunToCompletion Categorize Using
sci:arg.sci:help: Required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category, this parameter specifies the property or properties used to define the categories.
sci:arg.sci:validscript: SetInvalidDetails('This parameter is required when RunToCompletion is set to True - For Each Category'); Parameter() ne '';
sci:arg.sci:enabledscript: SetDisabledDetails('To Enable, Set RunToCompletion to True - For Each Category'); Parameter('RunToCompletion') eq 'True - For Each Category';

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options
sci:arg.sci:help:
When set to True, this set of options allow the subprotocol to execute in parallel on one or more independent Pipeline Pilot servers, running local or remote. Additional parameters control the number of data records to send in each process batch, the list of Pipeline Pilot servers to use, the number of protocol processes that can be executed on each server, and whether to preserve the order of the processed data records.

Use this option judiciously, since it will not increase throughput in all circumstances. In general, it will yield improved performance when the parallelization benefits outweigh the data transfer overhead for the specified batch size. As a rough guide, performance can be improved when each individual batch requires at least 10 seconds to execute, although this can be affected by the size of each data record.

When running the protocol with debugging, the subprotocol will provide debugging messages to detail each of the various steps of execution. Also, components located within the parallel subprotocol will display their debugging messages as well.

For more information on the parallel subprotocol options, see Parallel Processing Subprotocols.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Batch Size
sci:arg.sci:help:
The number of records to send to the remote server(s) for each subprotocol execution. In general, performance is optimized when the amount of time required to process each batch is at least 10 seconds (note that this can vary depending on the characteristics of the remote server's hardware). Use a batch size of -1 to pass all data in a single batch.

When RunToCompletion is set to "True - for each category", the batch sizes will be determined by the number of records in each individual category. Therefore, the Batch Size parameter is not applicable.

sci:arg.name: Parallel Processing Options Server
sci:arg.sci:help:
Comma separated list of Pipeline Pilot servers on which to execute the parallel subprotocol. The server names should be in the same format as the Pipeline Pilot Client's change server dialog (server-name:port-number).

Specifying localhost as a server will cause the subprotocol to use its own Pipeline Pilot server. This can be helpful on multi-CPU/multi-core systems (where the subprotocol jobs are spawned on the same machine) and Pipeline Pilot Linux clusters (where 'localhost' requests spawning the subprotocol jobs on the same cluster).
